div.p: All of these RESTful exchange mechanisms follow the same basic pattern - a resource of some type is transmitted from Data Source to Data Consumer using a simple REST command and the appropriate endpoint. The Data Consumer either stores the data as requested (and acknowledges that success with an appropriate HTTP code) or it rejects it. If accepted, a new 'version' of the resource is persisted at the specified endpoint and can potentially be referenced by other resources or subsequently queried or further manipulated. This transmits a single resource from the Data Source and causes it to be stored on the Data Consumer. A create uses the POST HTTP command and an update uses the PUT HTTP command. If successful, the requested record will be persisted at the RESTful endpoint with a reliable id, potentially allowing it to be queried or referenced in subsequent exchanges.
